content:
I've reformatted a bit, because, come on, Paragraphs. Use Them. Please.
Reworded a bit too, as UP and DOWN are likely going to be more readable in many situations as +/-, especially if you double - use as a punctuation mark.

And approved, because it now mostly fits all the rules, and who am I to refuse free XP.

But I'm certainly not upvoting. This problem would be so much more interesting if it "Lots Of Steps" actually meant "a lot". Like 2^63.
It would be so much more interesting this way that it's actually suspicious it didn't from the start, and make it feel like the statement was lifted from somewhere else.

You may add some testcase about the restriction "If it is commanded to go lower than 1st floor or higher than n-th floor, the elevator will not move and remain on its floor. "

like 10 7 6 5 6.  The answer should be "IMPOSSIBLE", but if don't care about the restriction, the answer will be "2".
I changed Validator 6 in order to have a big solution (not "IMPOSSIBLE")
I corrected the stub generator (input is on one line)

Why Validator 5 has output "Impossible"?
44+2-3*15 = 1 => output should be 16?

The problem is with the included solution

It only attempts to move in the direction towards the desired floor and doesn't see the option of moving away first

Also I think the test cases could be a little more difficult, for starters being a little closer to the advertised 10,000 floors (though even this bound seems like it could be higher)

Also expanding on this idea of moving away; you can make a test where you need to move towards and away multiple times before landing on the right floor, such as:
7 4 3 5 1
6 moves needed (5->2->6->3->7->4->1)

I'll try writing up a better solution that can find the correct solution to this and hopefully all possible test cases
I'll overwrite the provided solution later if that's alright with the OP
Testcase 5 is kind of considering this restriction

That's different. If you removed the restriction "If it is commanded to go lower than 1st floor or higher than n-th floor, the elevator will not move and remain on its floor. ",  test case 5 still "Impossible".

My point is, if you set some trick, you may design a test case to verify that trick.  When a solution doesn't consider that trick, it should failed in that test case.
